items.title: Tsunoda: AlphaTauri needs to run no wing to counter "horrible" top speed
items.description:
Tsunoda finished 10th in the Australian Grand Prix after spending much of the race fighting McLaren's Oscar Piastri.
Through Albert Park's fastest speed trap – at the second intermediate timing point – he was 17th fastest, logging 314.2 km/h compared to the 339.9 km/h of the fastest car, the Red Bull of Sergio Perez.
Speaking after scoring the team's first point of the year in Australia ...Keep reading

items.title: How Alfa Romeo's new front wing aims to improve entire F1 car
items.description:
The new nose and front wing aim to increase downforce and also help give the team more options to balance the car.
Alfa Romeo’s head of trackside engineering Xevi Pujolar said the downforce gains from the updates had wider benefits for the whole car. 
“We thought that front wing would bring back the car balance,” he explained. “I don't think we have particular weaknesses at ...Keep reading

items.title: Mercedes developing suspension updates to help Hamilton's 'disconnect'
items.description:
Hamilton noted at the Saudi Arabian Grand Prix that he didn’t “feel connected” to the car, and prior to the Australian GP he elaborated by suggesting the car’s cockpit is too far forward, affecting his feel for the steering.
Allison says Mercedes will take advantage of the gap in the schedule before the Azerbaijan GP at the end of April to work on mechanical elements of the W14 F1 car ...Keep reading

items.title: Williams F1 team hires new commercial boss
items.description:
Asencio will head up the team's commercial and marketing operations from New York, starting on 10 April, as the squad looks to grow its financial activities following the takeover by Dorilton Capital in August 2020.
The American's CV includes five years as UFC's senior vice president for global partnerships, where he was responsible for all commercial revenue, as well as almost two years in a ...Keep reading

items.title: Brown: Seidl departure helped with "aggressive" F1 technical review at McLaren
items.description:
After the Saudi Arabian GP, the team announced that technical director James Key had left and that a new arrangement had been put in place headed by three technical directors, namely Peter Prodromou (aerodynamics), Davide Sanchez (car concept and performance) and Neil Houldey (engineering and design).
Brown says that the changes were motivated by the lack of development of the 2022 car, and ...Keep reading
items.content:

Brown says that the changes were motivated by the lack of development of the 2022 car, and ...Keep reading

items.title: Krack: Too early to draw conclusions on Aston form
items.description:
Krack conceded that the Silverstone team was encouraged by the strong form shown across the first three tracks on the schedule, but insisted that small margins will make a difference from weekend to weekend.
Fernando Alonso took his third straight third place of the season in Melbourne, but the Spaniard was beaten to the flag by a car other than a Red Bull for the first time, with Lewis ...Keep reading

items.title: Why Mercedes feels its rapid F1 progress is still not good enough
items.description:
After rival Aston Martin emerged as Red Bull’s main threat in the Bahrain and Saudi Arabian Grands Prix, it was Mercedes that took the challenge to F1’s current pacesetter in Melbourne. 
George Russell secured a spot on the front row and led the early stages ahead of the first safety car period, while Lewis Hamilton then briefly took over at the front before Max Verstappen blasted past ...Keep reading

items.title: Ferrari confident of “mega step” at Australian GP despite no points
items.description:
The team had a disastrous Sunday afternoon in Melbourne terms of the F1 world championship, failing to score any points, as Charles Leclerc retired on the first lap after contact with Lance Stroll and Carlos Sainz tumbled from fourth to 12th place after taking a five-second penalty for causing a collision with Fernando Alonso.
Despite the obvious frustration, Vasseur said the team did at least ...Keep reading

Despite the obvious frustration, Vasseur said the team did at least ...Keep reading

items.title: Piastri: First F1 points in "crazy race" was good karma for McLaren
items.description:
Fortune went the way of both McLaren drivers during a hectic event at Albert Park, with the chaotic final restart leaving Piastri in eighth place and his team-mate Lando Norris in sixth.
McLaren didn’t score any points in the first two races, with Piastri retiring with an electrical issue in Bahrain and left stranded at the back of the field in Jeddah after suffering damage on the opening lap ...Keep reading

items.title: How AlphaTauri F1 floor updates helped address a core weakness
items.description:
After a disappointing start to the campaign, with its AT04 not making the step forward hoped for, the squad has worked hard to address areas where it felt it was especially lacking.
The first fruits of that labour appeared in Melbourne, where the team brought some key developments that it hoped would start it on a journey back nearer the front of the midfield pack. These were focused on the ...Keep reading
